title: Pays de France
text:
The Pays de France (, literally "Land of France"), also called the Parisis () or Plaine de France (), is a <a href="natural%20region">natural region</a> located in the <a href="%C3%8Ele-de-France">Île-de-France</a> <a href="administrative%20region">administrative region</a> to the north of <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, <a href="France">France</a>. It is essentially a <a href="silt">silt</a> <a href="plain">plain</a> devoted to <a href="cereal">cereal</a> <a href="crops">crops</a>, of which the southern part is included in the northern <a href="suburb">suburb</a>s of Paris and greatly urbanised, and also includes <a href="Charles%20de%20Gaulle%20Airport">Charles de Gaulle Airport</a>.
Administratively, the region corresponds approximately to the east of <a href="Val-d%27Oise">Val-d'Oise</a> <a href="departments%20of%20France">department</a>, with part of <a href="Seine-Saint-Denis">Seine-Saint-Denis</a> and the northwestern fringe of <a href="Seine-et-Marne">Seine-et-Marne</a>.
Geography.
Location.
The Pays de France is delimited in the south west by the <a href="Seine">Seine</a>, in the west by the forests of <a href="Montmorency%2C%20Val-d%27Oise">Montmorency</a> and <a href="Forest%20Carnelle">Carnelle</a>, in the east by the <a href="Marne%20%28river%29">River Marne</a> and the heights of <a href="Dammartin-en-Go%C3%ABle">Dammartin</a> and <a href="Multien%20and%20Go%C3%ABle">Goële</a>, and in the north by the <a href="Chantilly%20Forest">Chantilly Forest</a> and . It is bordered by the <a href="Vexin%20fran%C3%A7ais">Vexin français</a> to the west, by <a href="Brie%20%28region%29">Brie</a> to the east, by <a href="Multien%20and%20Go%C3%ABle">Multien and Goële</a> to the north east, and by <a href="Valois%20%28region%29">Valois</a> and the <a href="Pays%20de%20Thelle">Pays de Thelle</a> to the north. To the south are <a href="Mantois">Mantois</a>, <a href="Hurepoix">Hurepoix</a> and the <a href="Pays%20d%27Aulnoye">Pays d'Aulnoye</a>. In modern times, the <a href="Paris%20aire%20urbaine">Parisian agglomeration</a> has encroached on many of these traditionally defined areas and now makes up a new form of natural region.
Physical geography.
Two tectonic accidents have had a powerful influence on the geological structure of the Pays de France: the <a href="Seine">Seine</a> <a href="syncline">syncline</a> with the associated <a href="Saint-Denis%2C%20Seine-Saint-Denis">Saint-Denis</a> basin, in the west, and the <a href="Louvres%2C%20Val-d%27Oise">Louvres</a> <a href="anticline">anticline</a>, in the east.
The <a href="outcrop">outcrop</a>s, such as the <a href="Butte-Pinson">Butte-Pinson</a> at <a href="Montmagny%2C%20Val%20d%27Oise">Montmagny</a>, <a href="Pierrefitte-sur-Seine">Pierrefitte</a> and <a href="Villetaneuse">Villetaneuse</a> and the Butte d'Écouen at <a href="Villiers-le-Bel">Villiers-le-Bel</a> and <a href="%C3%89couen">Écouen</a>, contain significant deposits of <a href="gypsum">gypsum</a>; which was mined both in open pits and underground until the first half of the twentieth century. The mining has weakened the structure of the ground to the extent that several risk prevention plans need to be developed.
One very large depression, across, between <a href="Dugny">Dugny</a> and the Seine, is traversed by three small rivers: the Croult, the Vieille Mer and the Rouillon.
The upper <a href="water%20table">water table</a> (<a href="Eocene">Eocene</a> strata) includes two lower-level <a href="aquifer">aquifer</a>s up to in total height. It forms part of the general water table which is fed both by the watershed of the Seine and Marne and by lower aquifers. It is greatly influenced by <a href="precipitation%20%28meteorology%29">precipitation</a> and fluctuates significantly in depth, but in general lies close to the surface, requiring special care in sealing cellars and basements.
Until 1975, the aquifer was used for industrial purposes at <a href="Sevran">Sevran</a> and on the Saint-Denis Plain (the southern part of the Pays de France), and also for <a href="market%20gardening">market gardening</a>. Since the <a href="Bartonian">Bartonian</a> sub-aquifer contains too many minerals for human consumption, the <a href="Lutetian">Lutetian</a> sub-aquifer was occasionally tapped in <a href="Val-d%27Oise">Val-d'Oise</a>.
In order to limit seasonal rising of the water table, there are plans to find new urban applications for the water. This is recommended, for example, in the environmental plan for the <a href="agglomeration%20community">agglomeration community</a> of <a href="Plaine%20Commune">Plaine Commune</a>.
The Pays de France is a plain which has traditionally had a prosperous agricultural economy (particularly cereal crops and <a href="sugar%20beet">sugar beet</a>s) based on its fertile <a href="silt">silt</a> soils. Formerly there was extensive market gardening north of Paris; this has been progressively reduced by the expansion of built-up areas, industrial zones and warehouses.
Major north-south communication routes cross it—<a href="Route%20nationale%201">Route nationale 1</a>, the <a href="A1%20autoroute%20%28France%29">A1 autoroute</a> and the <a href="LGV%20Nord">LGV Nord</a>—and both <a href="Charles%20de%20Gaulle%20Airport">Charles de Gaulle</a> and <a href="Paris%E2%80%93Le%20Bourget%20Airport">Le Bourget</a> airports lie within it. The Le Bourget <a href="marshalling%20yard">marshalling yard</a> and the first <a href="bus%20station">bus station</a> in France, <a href="Garonor">Garonor</a>, are also located there. 
Human settlement.
The Plaine de France is one of the most fragile areas in the <a href="%C3%8Ele-de-France">Île-de-France</a>. It has been badly affected by the de-industrialisation of the region, since it had specialised in heavy industry, especially in the southern part, and several <a href="housing%20development">housing development</a>s had been built there to house the workers. A significant number of these developments have been the subject of <a href="urban%20renewal">urban renewal</a> projects, either instigated by or in association with the French National Association for Urban Renewal ("Agence nationale pour la rénovation urbaine" or ANRU). There are 32 <a href="sensitive%20urban%20zone">sensitive urban zone</a>s within it.
During the 1980s and 1990s, the middle classes tended to leave the area, and while the average income of Parisians and residents of the <a href="Hauts-de-Seine">Hauts-de-Seine</a> increased 23% between 1984 and 1998, that of residents of <a href="La%20Courneuve">La Courneuve</a>, <a href="Aubervilliers">Aubervilliers</a> or <a href="Sarcelles">Sarcelles</a> fell 15%.
The Plaine de France is undergoing profound changes. Every year, approximately 91,000 residents leave the area and an equivalent number settle there. Numerous urban renewal projects are underway, instigated by the municipalities or urban agglomerations such as Plaine Commune, often with the assistance of the regional governmental planning agency, the "Établissement public d'aménagement de la Plaine de France". Economic expansion is being driven by, for example, the <a href="Plaine%20Saint-Denis">Plaine Saint-Denis</a> and Charles de Gaulle Airport, which employs more than 85,000 people and creates associated jobs, notably in logistics.
The renewal of the area will be facilitated by planned upgrades to regional transportation infrastructure such as the <a href="RER%20B">RER B</a> and <a href="RER%20D">D</a> and the creation of new infrastructure such as the <a href="tram">tram</a>ways lines 5 and 8 (under construction), the planned <a href="Tangentielle%20Nord">Tangentielle Nord</a> railway and the <a href="CDG%20Express">CDG Express</a> rail link between Paris and Charles de Gaulle Airport (under study).
Name.
The word 'France' appears in the time of the first <a href="Merovingian">Merovingian</a>s, in the fifth century. In the 6th century it was used to designate the entire area granted <a href="Fee%20%28feudal%20tenure%29">in fief</a> by them, from the <a href="Rhine">Rhine</a> to the <a href="Loire">Loire</a>. In <a href="Carolingian">Carolingian</a> times, the area so designated was reduced to territory located between <a href="Austrasia">Austrasia</a> and <a href="Neustria">Neustria</a>, and during the tenth and eleventh centuries, was further reduced to apply only to the north east of Paris. There was doubtless a subdivision of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Paris">Diocese of Paris</a> corresponding to the area, the <a href="Archdeacon%23Catholic%20Church">Archdeaconry</a> of France.
The earliest preserved occurrence of the designation "de France" is in an 1126 document referring to the <a href="Basilica%20of%20St%20Denis">Abbey of St. Denis</a> as "Monasterii beati dyonisii de Francia". This abbey may be the reason for the extension of the designation to the whole region, since its possessions constituted a large part of the area. By the end of the Middle Ages, approximately all of today's region was referred to as "en France" or "de France". Beginning in the Renaissance, it was included in a larger territory termed the Île-de-France, while the area to the north east of Paris continued to be designated "France". Numerous documents of the "<a href="Ancien%20R%C3%A9gime">Ancien Régime</a>" make use of the term, which was then applied to 82 villages and hamlets.
During the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a>, the designation appears to have fallen into disuse. Currently, eight settlements ("<a href="Communes%20of%20France">commune</a>s") have it as part of their names: <a href="Baillet-en-France">Baillet-en-France</a>, <a href="Belloy-en-France">Belloy-en-France</a>, <a href="Bonneuil-en-France">Bonneuil-en-France</a>, <a href="Ch%C3%A2tenay-en-France">Châtenay-en-France</a>, <a href="Mareil-en-France">Mareil-en-France</a>, <a href="Puiseux-en-France">Puiseux-en-France</a>, <a href="Roissy-en-France">Roissy-en-France</a>, and since August 1989 <a href="Tremblay-en-France">Tremblay-en-France</a>, which was previously called Tremblay-lès-Gonesse.
History.
The Pays de France was inhabited by <a href="hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherer</a>s during the <a href="Lower%20Palaeolithic">Lower Palaeolithic</a>, as shown by <a href="Acheulean">Acheulean</a> and <a href="Levallois%20technique">Levallois</a> <a href="hand%20axe">hand axe</a>s and <a href="racloir">racloir</a>s which have been found at <a href="Gonesse">Gonesse</a>, <a href="Villiers-le-Bel">Villiers-le-Bel</a>, <a href="Fontenay-en-Parisis">Fontenay-en-Parisis</a>, <a href="Puiseux-en-France">Puiseux-en-France</a> and <a href="Louvres%2C%20Val-d%27Oise">Louvres</a>. Several finds also attest to <a href="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> occupation: polished or cut <a href="axe">axe</a>s and some drills or <a href="Scraper%20%28archaeology%29">scraper</a>s found in the area in the 1950s. Archaeological investigations in the Pays de France have identified more than 20 agricultural sites and three small settlements plus three fortified sites and an ancient burial ground.
During the <a href="Migration%20Age">Migration Age</a> and the Merovingian and Carolingian eras, there are few sources on the history of the area, merely mentions of some of the settlements: <a href="Luzarches">Luzarches</a>, <a href="%C3%89couen">Écouen</a>, <a href="%C3%89zanville">Ézanville</a>, <a href="Louvres%2C%20Val-d%27Oise">Louvres</a> and <a href="Mareil-en-France">Mareil-en-France</a>. Four <a href="necropolis">necropoles</a> have been uncovered at Luzarches, Mareil-en-France, <a href="Sarcelles">Sarcelles</a> and Thimécourt. But the current pattern of villages in the Pays de France did not develop until the twelfth century.
Beginning in the twelfth century, the Plaine de France was part of the original <a href="royal%20demesne">royal demesne</a> of the <a href="Capetian%20dynasty">Capetian kings</a>. Its location immediately adjacent to Paris made it economically dependent on the city from an early date. Thanks to its fertile soils, covered with a thick layer of <a href="silt">silt</a>, under the <a href="Ancien%20R%C3%A9gime">Ancien Régime</a> it provided food for the capital, especially <a href="cereal">corn</a> and bread from the bakeries at <a href="Gonesse">Gonesse</a>. For this reason also, it was a coveted area, divided into <a href="fief">fief</a>s also from the twelfth century on. The great monastic foundations of Paris and the region around it held a large acreage of agricultural land. In addition to the Abbey of St. Denis, which was established in the early Middle Ages, <a href="Chaalis%20Abbey">Chaalis Abbey</a> erected three very large <a href="Monastic%20grange">grange</a>s during the twelfth century for storing cereal crops, which were farmed with the assistance of <a href="lay%20brother">lay brother</a>s. The abbey estates of Stains at <a href="Villeneuve-sous-Dammartin">Villeneuve-sous-Dammartin</a>, Choisy-aux-Bœufs at <a href="V%C3%A9mars">Vémars</a> and <a href="Grange%20de%20Vaulerent">Vaulerent</a> at <a href="Villeron">Villeron</a> all exceed and were farmed intensively.
From the tenth to the seventeenth century, the majority of the Plaine de France was governed by the <a href="House%20of%20Montmorency">House of Montmorency</a>. Successive <a href="Duc%20de%20Montmorency">Dukes</a> constructed numerous castles and forts, for example the <a href="Ch%C3%A2teau%20d%27%C3%89couen">Château d'Écouen</a>, which dates to the sixteenth century. Beginning in the Renaissance, the area rose to prominence, with the renovation and expansion of churches and improvements to aristocratic residences to symbolise local power.
In the nineteenth century, railway lines were built and caused the development of urban centres around the new stations, as far north as <a href="Fosses">Fosses</a> and <a href="Survilliers">Survilliers</a> and as far east as <a href="Mitry-Mory">Mitry-Mory</a>. The first housing subdivisions developed, many to serve Parisians on holiday, and led to further urban development outside the old agricultural centres. In the twentieth century, the area then became an outlet for the rapid growth of the Parisian agglomeration, with its southern part industrialising and being massively urbanised by the development of popular housing estates along the <a href="Paris%E2%80%93Lille%20railway">Paris–Lille railway</a>, for example at 
<a href="Villiers-le-Bel">Villiers-le-Bel</a> and <a href="Goussainville%2C%20Val-d%27Oise">Goussainville</a>. This development continued between the wars, with further housing and <a href="Garden%20city%20movement">garden cities</a> being built in the still only lightly urbanised area. <a href="Villiers-le-Bel">Villiers-le-Bel</a>, <a href="Arnouville-l%C3%A8s-Gonesse">Arnouville-lès-Gonesse</a>, <a href="Gonesse">Gonesse</a>, <a href="Goussainville%2C%20Val-d%27Oise">Goussainville</a>, <a href="Aulnay-sous-Bois">Aulnay-sous-Bois</a> and <a href="Stains%2C%20Seine-Saint-Denis">Stains</a> grew by fifty to one hundred houses a year, gradually producing a suburban residential landscape.
After the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, large housing estates were rapidly built on cheap available land at 
places such as <a href="Saint-Denis%20%28Seine-Saint-Denis%29">Saint-Denis</a>, <a href="Sarcelles">Sarcelles</a>, <a href="Garges-l%C3%A8s-Gonesse">Garges-lès-Gonesse</a>, <a href="Aulnay-sous-Bois">Aulnay-sous-Bois</a>, <a href="Sevran">Sevran</a> and Tremblay-lès-Gonesse (now <a href="Tremblay-en-France">Tremblay-en-France</a>) in response to the post-war French housing crisis; this was connected to an <a href="Rural%20flight">exodus from the countryside</a> and to destruction of housing during the war, but also to the need to house people repatriated from <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a> (notably at <a href="Sarcelles">Sarcelles</a>) and to <a href="slum%20clearance">slum clearance</a>. The French government's creation of urban prioritisation zones ("<a href="Zone%20%C3%A0%20urbaniser%20en%20priorit%C3%A9">zones à urbaniser en priorité</a>") was one of the means facilitating the creation of these thousands of homes, which were urgently needed at the time, but had a severe effect on the southern part of the Pays de France, creating concentrations of poverty and "de facto" ethnic and social <a href="ghetto">ghetto</a>s.
The Pays de France also serves important functions for the functioning of the Parisian metropolitan area, notably in the area of logistics; for example, since the early 1970s <a href="Charles%20de%20Gaulle%20Airport">Charles de Gaulle Airport</a> has occupied there.
However, the northern half of the area retains its rural character, which has been protected by its partial integration into a regional <a href="nature%20park">nature park</a>, the <a href="Parc%20naturel%20r%C3%A9gional%20Oise-Pays%20de%20France">Parc naturel régional Oise-Pays de France</a>.
Tourism.
Because of its flatness and heavy concentration on growing cereal crops, the Pays de France has relatively little tourism. However, it has numerous interesting churches, particularly from the Renaissance, such as
St. Acceul at <a href="%C3%89couen">Écouen</a> (known particularly for its stained glass windows) and the churches at <a href="Villiers-le-Bel">Villiers-le-Bel</a>, <a href="Gonesse">Gonesse</a>, <a href="Luzarches">Luzarches</a> and <a href="Belloy-en-France">Belloy-en-France</a>, and also the picturesque hilltop village of <a href="Ch%C3%A2tenay-en-France">Châtenay-en-France</a>, which offers a view of the entire region. The <a href="Ch%C3%A2teau%20d%27%C3%89couen">Château d'Écouen</a>, built for <a href="Anne%20de%20Montmorency">Anne de Montmorency</a>, became the National Museum of the Renaissance in 1977.
The rural northern section of the region, with fifteen rural settlements, makes up the <a href="Parc%20naturel%20r%C3%A9gional%20Oise-Pays%20de%20France">Parc naturel régional Oise-Pays de France</a>, founded in 2004.
